channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Springsteen Plays to a Full Audience in Big Moment for Broadway
item.description: Fun fact: The captain of the $1 billion ship, Kate McCue, was the first American woman to captain a cruise ship in 2015. At least 95% of the passengers are vaccinated against Covid-19, operator Celebrity Cruises said, and the ship will sail at 35% capacity.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Virgin Galactic Receives FAA Clearance to Take Passengers to Space
item.description: Billionaire Sir Richard Branson’s space travel company Virgin Galactic received FAA clearance yesterday to fly paying customers to space—great news for the 600 people on its wait-list eager to glimpse the curvature of Earth from 56 miles up. Zoom out: Developments in space travel, specifically space tourism, are moving at lightning speed.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Consumer Spending Buoyed By Shoppers Updating Their Wardrobes
item.description: Nike predicted it’ll pass $50 billion in revenue this fiscal year for the first time thanks in part to a rapidly growing e-commerce biz. increased consumer spending sets the economy up for a strong summertime shopping season, as retailers race to open stores back up, hire elusive workers, and smooth out supply chain kinks to meet demand. Looking ahead...  A Harris Poll survey found that 61% of US adults’ weight fluctuated in the past year, with an average weight gain of 29 pounds among those that put on, rather than lost, weight.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 25
item.description: (Rolling Stone) Then he went too far. Read: David Dobrik was the king of YouTube. He told the AP he expects the pet business to keep booming as people move into larger, suburban houses and workplaces become more pet-friendly.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: BuzzFeed's Got a SPAC That Values the Media Company at $1.5 Billion
item.description: BuzzFeed hopes to scoop up more media companies and use that muscle to grab market share from the most powerful throuple in digital ads: Google, Facebook, and Amazon, which accounted for almost 90% of the US digital ad market in 2020, per ad agency GroupM. Now, BuzzFeed is in growth mode.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: President Biden, Group of Bipartisan Senators Reach an Infrastructure Deal
item.description: Some spending on child and elder care as well as education was cut from Biden's original plan.   don't start daydreaming about good train wi-fi yet, the plan still has a ways to go to become law. Looking ahead...  A corporate tax rate increase to fund the plan, which Biden originally proposed, was also ditched.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Microsoft Hits $2T Market Cap, Shows off Major Windows Update
item.description: . Microsoft was incorporated 40 years ago today, but instead of installing a barn door in its master bathroom, the company closed above a $2 trillion market cap for the first time this week and unveiled its first major Windows update in years.    Six bills that could reshape antitrust law in the US cleared a major hurdle yesterday morning. until now?
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: BuzzFeed's Got a SPAC That Values the Media Company at $1.5 Billion
item.description: BuzzFeed wants to scoop up more media companies and use that muscle to grab market share from the most powerful throuple in digital ads: Google, Facebook, and Amazon, which accounted for almost 90% of the US digital ad market in 2020, per ad agency GroupM. Now, BuzzFeed is in growth mode.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.description: (Rolling Stone) Then he went too far. Read: David Dobrik was the king of YouTube. He told the AP he expects the pet business to keep booming as people move into larger, suburban houses and workplaces become more pet-friendly.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: President Biden, Group of Bipartisan Senators Reach an Infrastructure Deal
item.description: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said her chamber would only take up the infrastructure plan if Democrats were able to push through a separate spending package. don't start daydreaming about good train wi-fi yet, because the plan still has a ways to go to become law. Looking ahead...
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Microsoft Hits $2T Market Cap, Shows off Major Windows Update
item.description: . Microsoft was incorporated 40 years ago today, but instead of installing a barn door in its master bathroom, the company closed above a $2 trillion market cap for the first time this week and unveiled its first major Windows update in years.    Six bills that could reshape antitrust law in the US cleared a major hurdle yesterday morning. until now?
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Resorts World Opens in Las Vegas
item.description: Big picture: Las Vegas is firmly in a post-Covid mentality right now, bringing visitors back to its business conventions and entertainment options. large:With a price tag of $4.3 billion, Resorts World is the most expensive property ever developed in the city.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 24
item.description: (Medium)  Read: Why didn’t bullet journaling work for me? Buffett has pledged to give away about 99% of his net worth.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Britney Spears Asks Judge to End Her Conservatorship in Public Testimony
item.description: In her most public statement to date about her personal affairs, Britney Spears told an LA probate judge that she wants to end the conservatorship she's been under for 13 years." Big picture: Spears’s story gained traction after her fans started the #FreeBritney movement in 2019.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Hong Kong’s Largest Pro-Democracy Paper Shuts Down
item.description: the former chair of the Hong Kong Journalists Association said, “Police did not rule out the possibility of more arrests, and the next [target] could be other media.”  Radio Television Hong Kong (RTHK) was forced to swap its station head with a career politician with no journalism experience.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Supreme Court Hands Down Major Rulings on Farms, Free Speech, and Fannie and Freddie
item.description: Yesterday, the Supreme Court struck down a regulation that allowed union organizers to meet with agricultural workers during some periods of the day. The Supreme Court didn’t buy that, but did concede that the structure of the agency that oversees Fannie and Freddie is unconstitutional.  Bottom line: Because Levy didn’t bully anyone or post her frustrations during school, SCOTUS said she had the right to be an angry teen. The school banned Levy from cheer for a full year and her (clearly cool) dad got the ACLU involved, claiming that the school violated her First Amendment rights.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Britney Spears Asks Judge to End Her Conservatorship in Public Testimony
item.description: Yesterday, Britney Spears gave a public statement to an LA County Superior Court about her 13-year conservatorship, the first time she’s spoken publicly since 2019. . Spears’s story is one filled with speculation, but yesterday’s statement was the first time she publicly spoke against the conservatorship and her father.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Hong Kong’s Largest Pro-Democracy Paper Shuts Down
item.description: the former chair of the Hong Kong Journalists Association said, “Police did not rule out the possibility of more arrests, and the next [target] could be other media.”  Radio Television Hong Kong (RTHK) was forced to swap its station head with a career politician with no journalism experience.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Resorts World Opens in Las Vegas
item.description: Big picture: Las Vegas is firmly in a post-Covid mentality right now, attracting visitors back to its business conventions and entertainment options. large:With a price tag of $4.3 billion, Resorts World is the most expensive property ever developed in the city.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Supreme Court Hands Down Major Rulings on Farms, Free Speech, and Fannie and Freddie
item.description: The Supreme Court didn’t buy that, but did concede that the structure of the agency that oversees Fannie and Freddie is unconstitutional. Yesterday, the Supreme Court struck down a regulation that allowed union organizers to meet with agricultural workers during their lunch breaks and for one hour before and after their shifts, on up to 120 days a year.  Bottom line: Because Levy didn’t bully anyone or post her frustrations during school, SCOTUS said she had the right to be an angry teen. The school banned Levy from cheer for a full year and her (clearly cool) dad got the ACLU involved, claiming that the school violated her First Amendment rights.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Brew Mini: Query
item.author: Mary Tobler

item.title: Airlines Struggle to Handle Surge in Unruly Passengers and In-Flight Violence
item.description: Someone needs to take away the FAA’s photoshop. While we’re here... American is cutting 1% of July flights and Delta announced plans to hire 1,000 more pilots by next summer.  Big picture: In general, airlines are struggling to accommodate the rebound in demand.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 23
item.description: (The Ringer) Read: The rise of the $10 million disc golf celebrity.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Blackstone to Buy Rental Firm Home Partners of America for $6B
item.description: Now, the firm (and others) want back in on the soaring housing market, where last month median home prices rose almost 24% annually to break $350k. After the 2008 crash, Wall Street firms like Blackstone scooped up foreclosed homes on the cheap.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: US Likely Won’t Hit Vaccination Goal by Fourth of July, Says White House
item.description: Bottom line: Health officials are painting a portrait of “two Americas,” one in regions with high immunization rates and the other where they lag. Vaccines have been shown to protect against delta, but experts are warning of surges in regions with lower vaccination rates—like the South—this fall and winter.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Tinder Rolls Out Biggest Update in Years
item.description: Bottom line: With lockdowns mostly over, people are turning to dating apps to find new friends, benefits included or not. Some dating apps are taking a different approachBumble, an app known for requiring women to make the first move, is doubling down on its “Bumble BFF” feature to help nurture IRL friendships. And Match Group, which owns Tinder, recently acquired a South Korean company, Hyperconnect, that promotes conversations across borders and languages.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Tinder Rolls Out Biggest Update in Years
item.description: Videos: Tinder is letting users attach up to nine short videos to their profiles. Some dating apps are taking a different approachBumble, an app known for requiring women to make the first move, is doubling down on its “Bumble BFF” feature to help nurture IRL friendships. When dating in 2021, it pays to be hot on the inside. Bottom line: With lockdowns mostly over, people are turning to dating apps to find friends, benefits included or not.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Airlines Struggle to Handle Surge in Unruly Passengers and In-Flight Violence
item.description: Someone needs to take away the FAA’s photoshop. While we’re here... American is cutting 1% of July flights and Delta announced plans to hire 1,000 more pilots by next summer.  Big picture: In general, airlines are struggling to accommodate the rebound in demand.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: US Likely Won’t Hit Vaccination Goal by Fourth of July, Says White House
item.description: Bottom line: Health officials are painting a portrait of “two Americas,” one in regions with high immunization rates and the other where they lag. Vaccines have been shown to protect against delta, but experts are warning of surges in regions with lower vaccination rates—like the South—this fall and winter.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Word Search
item.author: Mary Tobler

item.title: Wingstop Launches Chicken Thigh Brand, Thighstop
item.description: Thighstop won't just be a departure from Wingstop's namesake business. Wingstop's wholesale prices have risen from as little as 98 cents last year to over $3 now, according to the company's CEO.  Zoom out: Changing demographics have boosted dark meat's popularity in recent years.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 22
item.description: (NYT Magazine) Can it be fixed?  Read: Covid proved the CDC was broken. She's not alone: More people quit the retail industry in April (~649,000) than any other month on record.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Spielberg's Amblin Partners Agrees to Make Movies for Netflix
item.description: The company has agreed to produce two or more movies a year for the streamer, some of which could be directed by Spielberg himself. Bottom line: Striking a deal with Spielberg is a flex for Netflix; he has more Oscars under his belt than any other living filmmaker.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: WeWork Posts Best 2-Month Sales Streak Since 2019
item.description: More offices are looking for hybrid or remote-friendly setups, and WeWork is once again poised to scratch the labor market's newest itch. WeWork is tracking for $1.9 billion in revenue and aims to go public this year exactly how you'd expect: a $9 billion SPAC deal with BowX Acquisition Corp.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Supreme Court Ruling Over Athlete Compensation Deals Blow to NCAA
item.description: College athletes scored another big W in their looooong quest to get paid for their work on the field. For its part, the NCAA claims that compensating student athletes would undermine the “amateur” flavor of college sports, damaging fans' enjoyment of the product. At least seven states have passed bills allowing college athletes to make money from their names, images, and likenesses that go into effect next week. Yesterday, the US Supreme Court ruled unanimously that the NCAA cannot stop colleges from compensating student athletes, as long as that compensation is tied to education.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Wingstop Launches Chicken Thigh Brand, Thighstop
item.description: Thighstop won't just be a departure from Wingstop's namesake business. Wingstop's wholesale prices have risen from as little as 98 cents last year to over $3 now, according to the company's CEO.  Zoom out: Changing demographics have boosted dark meat's popularity in recent years.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Supreme Court Ruling Over Athlete Compensation Deals Blow to NCAA
item.description: College athletes scored another big W in their looooong quest to get paid for their work on the field. For its part, the NCAA claims that compensating student athletes would undermine the “amateur” flavor of college sports, damaging fans' enjoyment of the product. If more justices adopt Kavanaugh's aggressive stance, “It could only be a matter of time before all of the NCAA's restrictions on compensation are struck down as antitrust violations,” Tulane sports law administrator Gabe Feldman told the NYT.
item.author: Neal Freyman
